Description: Shoulder sherd of Attic black-figured pottery hydria; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of lower part of Amazon, to left, falling back, having been wounded in the thigh by a sword or spear with brown shaft; wearing a short cloak and legging-style trousers decorated with added white circles (each with white dot in the middle); large patch in added red on her left thigh indicating the bleeding wound; her preserved foot is white over black; to right, lower part of draped figure with red on himation standing to left and holding spear; below, red band situated just below the marked carination at the shoulder-body transition.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd is also published by von Bothmer, D., Amazons in Greek Art. Oxford 1957, 46, no. 89, 48, pl. 37, no. 7 (Attic).
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 296, no. B282)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0111) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 87, pl. X, no. 9) (registered as Clazomenian)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
